newsitem.title: USA: U.S. spot natgas prices extend gains on heat.
newsitem.headline: U.S. spot natgas prices extend gains on heat.

text.p: U.S. spot natural gas prices continued to strengthen Tuesday as warmer-than-normal weather stretched across the U.S., market sources said.
Louisiana Gulf Coast prices firmed about two cents to the high-$2.20s per mmBtu, while south Texas prices rose by a similar amount to the low-$2.20s.

Above-normal temperatures are forecast to continue throughout most of the eastern half of the U.S. this week, though a brief bout of thunderstorms is expected to pressure temperatures later this week in parts of the Midwest, according to Weather Services Corp.
In the East, New York city gate prices gained another two to five cents to the low-$2.60s as temperature highs in the area neared 90 degrees F amid partly cloudy skies.
In the Midwest, prices were also up about two cents to $2.10-2.13, while Chicago city-gate prices still hovered around $2.40.
Some traders said they were expecting Midwest prices to soften slightly later this week in anticipation of heavy rains and the resulting drop in cooling demand.
In West Texas, Permian prices edged about two cents higher to about $2.07-2.12, while southern California border prices remained strong at $2.25-2.27.
Early July prices in the Permian basin were talked at $2.06-2.07, which would be even with June indices.
